"Part art, part science, effective messages are key to the success of any campaign.

We’ll work closely with you to create the messages that will move your key audiences. We use research, data, media analyses and more to find out what your target audiences care about and what will move them to act.

Resource Media writes, edits and produces comprehensive message guides on a range of topics to help you and your partners stay on message. Designed as a strategy, training and reference tool, we distribute them to coalitions, campaigns and others to guide their work."

Could part of the public's failure to connect the dots between global warming and more frequent summer heat waves, spring flooding events, massive hurricanes, and so on be due to the refusal of the press to connect the dots between those events as they happen and global warming?

Any perusal of news stories over the past decade reveals that the press, across the board, won't link record events to global warming - they're more than willing to link them to "natural cycles" such as La Nina or El Nino in the weather section. Furthermore, voices that claim "natural cycles" are responsible for 20th century warming trends (now 21st century) have been given way to much credence.

For example, Don Easterbrook has loudly and vehemently proclaimed that a Pacific Ocean cooling cycle is imminent based on so-called PDO trends. How much coverage has say, Dot Earth given to this largely evidence-free claim?

http://dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com...

http://dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com...

Those Easterbrook quotes have been widely recirculated and now form the basis of fossil fuel lobbyist talking points - now Barton and Inhofe are making these claims.

They are never asked, however, how that fits with the ongoing trends in extreme weather - and a primary reason is the press taboo against linking the subjects of climate and weather in any detail - much as there is a taboo against detailing the links between governmental energy policies, the fossil fuel business sector, and the failure of international institutions to address global warming.

Consider, for example, this 2007 quote from Don Easterbrook:

"Prof Don Easterbrook, a geologist at Western Washington University, believes the Earth is in the grip of a 30-year warming cycle. He said: "Past climatic trends indicate that global climates should begin to cool sometime between now and 2010."

http://www.telegraph.co.uk...

So, should we now expect a public debunking of the ocean cooling and solar cooling myths that this cohort has so doggedly promoted, complete with front page headlines? Or, like the debunked assaults on climate models by Soon & Baliunas in the 1990s (the Arctic isn't melting!), will it all be ignored in favor of dozens of stories on the next email scandal?

In reality, the conclusions of individual climate papers published in leading journals are more than sufficient to prove the case, and if people in policy-making positions were presented with that work and those conclusions, then they wouldn't need an IPCC group to write up an executive summary.

There are probably a dozen key papers in each of the following categories:

1) Arctic and Antarctic trends in surface temperature, ice melt, and ocean current warming.
2) Regional trends in glacial cover, snow cover, soil moisture and precipitation.
3) Global shifts in the frequency & intensity of extreme weather events.
4) The match between climate models and satellite observations, radiosondes, ocean buoys, etc.
5) Climate-linked shifts in ecosystems - animal and plant distributions, extinction and migration.
6) Global ocean warming and similar issues - ocean hypoxia/anoxia & ocean acidification.

The IPCC merely lumps all those papers together in one place, making a convenient target for those who wish to discredit the science by whatever means available. Rather than try and argue that the science itself is flawed, an effort sure to end in failure, they now seek to discredit the IPCC process with various smears and innuendos, and, sad to say, the press - corporate or non-profit, that doesn't matter - can't really be trusted to be impartial, if the prior record is any indication. Scientists will have no choice but to communicate via press release, if their comments will otherwise be taken out of context or otherwise distorted - recall the Carl Wunsch incident?

http://www.realclimate.org...

Who needs that? Instead, give the reporter a list of references and refuse any meetings until they've done their homework - if they're pushing some agenda, you won't hear from them again.

This is the third response to comments on the post on our blog ClimateEthics.org

A few commentators disagree with the claim that one can ever appeal to ethical principles that have any claim to universal validity and then often site something like abortion in support of their claim. Without denying that many human problems can not be resolved by examination of ethical principles, most ethicists point to some problems about which there is an overlapping consensus among most ethical positions. Climate change surprisingly raises many issues about which such universal claims can be made. One place to look for universal agreement is when nations have actually agreed in either soft or hard law documents that certain principles represent ethically responsible behavior of nations. In the case of climate change, the United States and 180 other countries have already agreed on the following in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change that:
1. No nation may harm another nation by its release of greenhouse gases, or more specifically that nations "have the responsibility to ensure that activities within their jurisdiction or control do not cause damage to the environment of other States or of areas beyond the limits of national jurisdiction,"
2. All nations should as of 1992 adopt policies to prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system based upon equity (notice not national interest)
3. No country may use scientific uncertainty as an excuse for taking cost-effect actions to reduce the threat of climate change. (This is a principle widely ignored by opponents to climate change policies)
4. The developed country Parties should take the lead in combating climate change and the adverse effects thereof.
5. The developed countries (including the US have special responsibilities to the least developed countries for climate change. (By the way this principle was agreed to by George Bush the first in 1992 because it was clear to by all that the rich countries have caused most of the climate change problem and this is very well documented by negotiators at that time

Most opponents of climate change policies in the United States either are ignorant of these well settled normative principles or choose to ignore them. If there position is that the United States should not be bound by them, even though it is by the force law and and the US promise in ratifying the UNFCCC ,that makes these principles universally binding, opponents at the very minimum, should be required to identify rational arguments why these principles don't represent ethical minimums. Yet, time and time again we hear opponents of climate change policies appeal to short term economic arguments that implicitly deny that the United States has duties to prevent harm to others from climate change, a matter which is well settled. This puts the opponents of climate change policies in the position of basing their entire position on lack of scientific poof for climate change damages. Yet, the US has already agreed it would not use this excuse in the UNFCCC, as a matter of ethics, as we explained before, the burden of proof for something so dangerous lies with the skeptics, and the no harm principle has been interpreted by international courts to require nations to take action that could cause harm once they are on reasonable notice that their actions could cause harm, that is long, long before absolute proof is available.

In addition although clauses such as "all nations should reduce their emissions on the basis of equity to prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system" requires further interpretation and therefore are questions which different parties might reasonably disagree about, not all interpretations of this requirement are entitled to respect as a matter of ethics just because some disagree. For instance, I cant say I am entitiled to emit more ghg becaue I have brown eyes. Principles of distributive justice require that differences of how burdens should be shared must be based upon morally relevant reasons. One of the arguments that this principle excludes is the one most frequently heard in the US, the US should not reduce its emissions because it hurts US ieconimic terests. This passes no ethical test. Ethics and international law requires the US to acknowledge, duties, responsibilities and obligations to others for climate change not base domestic policy on on national interest. Yet, all most all arguments against US policy on climate change appear ethither cost arguments to the US alone (an argument which by the ways conveniently ignores the cost on non-action to the whole world.) or claims that there is no scientific proof.

And so strong ethical principles can be made about some climate change issues, others are subject to reasonable disagreement, and others we can spot injustice even though we may disagree about what justice requires. Donald A. Brown, Penn State

"...accumulating observations and analysis pointing to the causes and consequences of global warming merely delineate the problem,..." you say. What accumulating evidence? Using NOAA's database of weather balloon observations Ferenc Miskolczi has shown that the infrared optical thickness of the atmosphere has not changed for the last 61 years. What this means is that constant addition of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere for the last 61 years has not had any influence on the already-existing greenhouse effect. To put it another way: the infrared absorption band of the atmosphere is saturated and does not respond to addition of carbon dioxide to air. Others have made this claim but now we have empirical confirmation of it. Climate change does exist but it is not caused by carbon dioxide - that is the key observation that the global warming enthusiasts have to reconcile themselves with. NASA tried to suppress his work but he quit. Look for his latest work in Energy & Environment.

His work seems to be hotly disputed.

Dear Andy,

Your comment "Keep in mind the IPCC only assesses existing research (and some of that wonderful "gray" literature)" rang a bell in my memory.

Were we not assured, by Rajendra Pachauri himself last fall, during the brouhaha about the Indian government's repudiation of the "Himalayan glaciers gone by 2035" story, that there was no chance of the IPCC being wrong about anything, since all their assertions were based only on peer-reviewed science?

Since then we have learned that the shambles over WGII's risible "Impacts" assessments results very largely from their incautious reliance on these dramatic "gray" literature statements from advocacy groups.

Einstein is often quoted thus; "Insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result."

Now IPCC is having the same people (Pachauri et al) do the same thing (set up an opaque process run by advocate-"scientists" passing judgments on their own work).

Surely they, the IPCC and all who rely on them, are not insane enough to expect a different result this time.

http://www.woodfortrees.org...

http://www.woodfortrees.org...

shows that the pattern 1910-1950 is EXACTLY reproduced by the pattern 1970-2010 (including the last 10 years of cooling.) It is therefore natural, not caused by higher CO2 emissions.

The best measured glaciers in the world show EXACTLY the same 60 year period. They melt now the same way they did in 1950.

http://glaciology.ethz.ch...

so the melting can only be natural.

The same pattern shows that we are likely to have the current global cooling continue for another 20 years until 2030, similarly to the 1940-1970 cooling.

None of the IPCC models has predicted or can explain the current decade of global cooling measured by both our satellites.

Maintaining the credibility of a panel based on global warming prevention during thirty years of measured global cooling will not be easy, reviews or not.

So the IPCC's big problem is the fact that its statements are contradicted by actual Earth climate measurements. It is not papers or opinions or panel reviews.
